awd_titl_txt: Terahertz Response of Unique Composite Metamaterials
awd_abstract_narration:
ECCS -0725764
Weili Zhang, Oklahoma State University 

Metamaterials, with both negative permittivity and negative permeability, have opened up an entirely new world of devices that may lead to breakthrough applications in a broad range of disciplines. This project focuses on investigation of composite subwavelength-structured metamaterials using techniques of terahertz spectroscopy. The longer-term goal of this program is to develop integrated and efficient terahertz circuit elements capable of being integrated into compact platforms for applications in aerospace communications and surveillance systems, optoelectronics, and biosensing.

Intellectual Merit: The proposed program encompasses multiple research efforts to develop metamaterials functioning at terahertz frequencies. The state-of-the-art terahertz spectroscopy technology will be used to characterize the electrical and magnetic properties of terahertz metamaterials. Novel metamaterial configurations with enhanced magnetic response and low loss will be explored to establish negative index of refraction in the terahertz regime. A proof-of-concept examination of potential use of metamaterials in biosensing will be undertaken. The PIs also propose to explore unique semiconductor metamaterials that exhibit instantaneous electric and magnetic response to electromagnetic radiation. Additionally, magnetic terahertz surface plasmons will be investigated at the surface of two-dimensional metamaterials. 

Broader Impact: The proposed program will enable development of terahertz technology and new generation integrated optoelectronic devices that will impact a broad range of disciplines, particularly aerospace communications, biosensing, and terahertz imaging. The PIs would continue their collaboration with industry in developing terahertz components and microsensors. A new graduate level course, introduction to metamaterials, will be developed for photonics students. New topics in metamaterials will be implemented in an ongoing ?cleanroom open house? program offered to high school students, particularly the Oklahoma Native Americans. The PIs will also team up with other colleagues to develop programs in optical science for K-12 students.

por.por_cntn:
Metamaterials, with negative permittivity, negative permeability, or both, are promising in developing unique photonic devices for applications in a broad range of disciplines. This project focuses on investigations of the unique terahertz (THz) responses of composite metamaterials using the state-of-the-art techniques of THz spectroscopy, cleanroom microelectronic processing, and numerical simulations. The research findings and accomplishments resulting from this project are described in the following sequence: unique response of planar THz metamaterials and negative index of refraction, chiral THz metamaterials, metamaterial-induced transparency, proof-of-concept sensing with THz metamaterials, and three-dimensional (3D) THz cloaking.

 1) Unique responses of planar THz metamaterials and negative index of refraction. Systematic investigations have been carried out to study electromagnetic properties of planar metamaterials at THz frequencies. Using highly reproducible subwavelength resonators, we showed that the inductive-capacitive (LC) resonance could be developed in planar metamaterials made from both generally good and poor metals with either optically thick or optically thin thicknesses. We also demonstrated superconducting THz metamaterials (Fig. 1a), random metamaterials, spiral metamaterial antennas, and resonant properties of metallic split-ring resonators (SRRs) at oblique incidence, cryo-temperature, and with breaking symmetry. The LC resonance was found to exhibit strong dependence on the permittivity of metals at THz frequencies; it was enhanced with a higher ratio of the real to the imaginary parts of the permittivity. We have also observed THz negative index of refraction in a freestanding metamaterial fabricated by use of a unique double-layer, self-aligned photolithography. Such flexible texture, straightforward fabrication process, and interesting resonant properties are promising in developing 3D THz metamaterials and metamaterial-based THz components.  

 2) Chiral THz metamaterials. Chirality and asymmetric THz transmission have been studied in various unique metamaterials. A 3D chiral metamaterial with strong chirality and negative index of refraction was demonstrated at THz frequencies. Composed of more than a hundred thousand 40 µm × 40 µm gold unit cells, the chiral metamaterial revealed a negative index in the frequency range of 1.06-1.27 THz, as shown in Fig. 1b. Different from the Veselago metamaterials, the chirality, as opposed to mirror symmetry, enabled the creation of a negative index of refraction while it did not require the permittivity and permeability to be simultaneously negative. The realization of THz chiral negative-index metamaterials offers opportunities for investigations of their novel electromagnetic properties, such as negative refraction and reflection, as well as important THz device applications. In addition, we have also observed chiral behaviors and asymmetric THz transmission in planar chiral (Fig. 1c) and non-chiral metamaterials.

 3)  Metamaterial-induced transparency. The coupling or interference effect in certain metamaterials may lead to narrow, low-loss, and strong dispersive resonances that could mimic the well-known quantum phenomenon, electromagnetically induced transparency (EIT). Our recent THz time-domain spectroscopy (THz-TDS) and numerical studies have shown that specially designed planar metamaterials resonating at THz frequencies can exhibit spectral response that resembled the EIT effect. In Fig. 1d  we show the spectral coupling between a dark and a bright eigenmode in a metamaterial with broken symmetry. For normal incidence and a fixed polarization, both eigenmodes can be excited with one of them regarded as dark state since coupling was prohibited due to symmetry constraints. Similar transparency resonance was also observed in another metamaterial made from unit cells consisting of a SRR surrounded by a larger closed ring.

4) Proof-of-concept sensing with THz metamaterials. Metamaterials have arisen as a candidate for chemical or biological detection because of their subwavelength dimensions and a resonance response that is tunable by design. This idea primarily capitalizes on the structure of SRRs, whose natural oscillation frequencies depend critically on the permittivity of the boarding dielectrics as we have experimentally demonstrated. Our proof-of-concept studies of thin-film sensing with planar metamaterials have revealed noticeable resonance shift with even a 100 nm-thick overlayer film applied on the SRR surface. The results have illustrated many of the factors involved in sensing optimization, such as ring geometry, substrate composition, analyte composition and deposition,  resonance effects and limitations of the THz measurement system, and have presented a promising outlook for THz sensing technology. 

 5) Three-dimensional terahertz cloaking. The invisibility cloak has been a long-standing dream for researchers over the decades. It is of particular importance that a cloaking device could be realized in 3D with the ability to cloak an object of realistic size. Recently, we experimentally demonstrated a 3D ground plane cloak functioning at terahertz frequencies. The 3D cloaking device was fabricated using the projection microstereolithography (PµSL) technique and experimentally characterized using reflection THz-TDS. The measured THz radiation reflected from the uncloaked bump exhibited two distinct peaks and one minor peak in between. In contrast, the reflection from the cloaked bump revealed an expected flat wavefront, as if the bump did not exist, indicating that the object placed underneath the reflective bump can be cloaked.
